{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox artist | name = Rita Keegan | image = | image_size = 200px | caption = img caption | birth_name = Rita Morrison | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1949}} | birth_place = [[New York City|New York]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = | field = [[Painting]], digital art | training = [[High School of Art and Design]], [[San Francisco Art Institute]] | movement = | known_for = | works = | awards = }}
'''Rita Keegan''' (born 1949) is an American-born artist, lecturer and [[archivist]], based in England since the late 1970s. She is a multi-media artist whose work uses video and digital technologies.<ref name="Desire 1999" /> Keegan is best known for her involvement with in the UK's [[BLK Art Group|Black Arts Movement]] in the 1980s and her work documenting artists of colour in Britain.
==Biography== Born Rita Morrison<ref name="Companion 2002" /> in the [[Bronx]], [[New York City]],<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iG2Dosvm2yU "Rita Keegan"] (YouTube video, posted 9 August 2013), SamtheWheels, 2008.</ref> to a [[Dominica]]n mother and Canadian father,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Chambers|first1=Eddie|title=Four x 4: installations by sixteen artists in four galleries|location=Bristol|date=1991|publisher=E. Chambers}}</ref> she described her upbringing in the [[Bronx]] as having "more in common with an English/Commonwealth background".<ref name="WASL Journal 1987">{{cite journal|last1=Rendell|first1=Clare|title=Actual Lives of Women Artists - Rita Keegan 19887|journal=Women Artists Slide Library Journal|date=October 1987|issue=19|pages=10–11}}</ref> She graduated from the [[High School of Art and Design]] focusing on illustration and costume design, then obtained a fine arts degree at the [[San Francisco Art Institute]],<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Buckman|editor1-first=David|title=Dictionary of Artists in Britain Since 1945|date=2006|publisher=Art Dictionaries|isbn=9780953260959}}</ref> where her teachers included the photographer [[Imogen Cunningham]] and the African-American artist Mary O'Neill.<ref name="WASL Journal 1987" /> Keegan moved to London, England, in the late 1970s.<ref name="Desire 1999">{{cite book|title=Desire By Design: Body, Territories and New Technologies|date=1999|editor=Cutting Edge, The Women's Research Group|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=9781860642807|page=237|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=sqEcQoTr-7EC&pg=PA237&lpg=PA237&dq#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
Keegan originally trained as a painter but in the 1980s begin to incorporate lens-based media, using the photocopier and computer in both 2D and installation work.<ref name="Mute 1997">{{cite web|last1=Taylor|first1=Stuart|title=Rita Keegan on Digital Diversity and the Colour of Computers|url=http://www.metamute.org/editorial/articles/rita-keegan-digital-diversity-and-colour-computers|website=Mute|accessdate=1 December 2015|date=10 January 1997}}</ref> In 1984 she worked at "Community Copyart" in London. The [[Greater London Council|GLC]]-funded organisation was an affordable resource centre for voluntary groups to create they own print material in addition to working with artists who wanted to use the photocopier as a form of printmaking.<ref name="Community Printshops 2015">{{cite book|author1=Baines, Jess|editor1-last=Uldam|editor1-first=Julie|editor2-last=Vestergaard|editor2-first=Anne|title=Civic Engagement and Social Media: Political Participation Beyond Protest|date=2015|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=9781137434166|page=190|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=4uq_CQAAQBAJ&lpg=PA190&dq=%E2%80%9CCommunity%20Copyart%E2%80%9D&pg=PA190#v=onepage&q=%E2%80%9CCommunity%20Copyart%E2%80%9D&f=false|chapter=Nurturing Dissent? Community Printshops in 1970s London}}</ref>
Keegan was a founding member of the artists' collectives [[Brixton Artists Collective|Brixton Art Gallery]] in 1982, and later Women's Work and Black Women in View. She went on to co-curate ''Mirror Reflecting Darkly'', Brixton Art Gallery's first exhibition by the Black Women Artists collective.<ref name="TrAIN 2011">{{cite web|title=TrAIN Conversation - Françoise Dupré and Rita Keegan in conversation with Deborah Cherry - BRIXTON CALLING!|url=http://www.transnational.org.uk/events/151-train-conversation-franoise-dupr-and-rita-keegan-in-conversation-with-deborah-cherry-brixton-calling-|website=|publisher=[[University of the Arts London]], Research Centre for Transnational Art, Identity and Nation|accessdate=21 September 2015}}</ref> From 1985 Keegan was a staff member at the [[Women Artists Slide Library]] (WASL), where she established and managed the [[Women Artists of Colour Index]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Arya|first1=Rina|title=Chila Kumari Burman: Shakti, Sexuality and Bindi Girls|date=2012|publisher=KT Press|isbn=0953654133|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=OqgiAwAAQBAJ&lpg=PT67&dq=%22rita%20keegan%22&pg=PT67#v=onepage&q=%22rita%20keegan%22&f=false}}</ref> She was Director of the [[African and Asian Visual Arts Archive]] from 1992 to 1994.<ref name="Companion 2002" />
Keegan taught New Media and Digital Diversity at [[Goldsmiths, University of London]], where she also helped establish the digital-media undergraduate course in the Historical and Cultural Studies department.<ref name="Companion 2002">{{cite book|author1=Cheddie, Janice|chapter=Keegan, Rita|editor1-last=Donnell|editor1-first=Alison|editorlink=Alison Donnell|title=Companion to Contemporary Black British Culture|date=2002|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781134700257|page=167|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=VfdpdZ9DwH0C&lpg=PA167&ots=n9ETv8lE_K&dq=Companion%20to%20Contemporary%20Black%20British%20Culture%20rita%20keega&pg=PA167#v=onepage&q=Companion%20to%20Contemporary%20Black%20British%20Culture%20rita%20keega&f=false}}</ref><ref name="TrAIN 2011" />
==Selected exhibitions== *2006: ''Transformations'', Lewisham Arthouse and [[Horniman Museum]], London (solo)<ref name=Horniman>{{cite web|title=Exhibitions and Special Exhibits since 1948|url=http://www.horniman.ac.uk/about/exhibitions-and-special-exhibits-since-1948|publisher=Horniman Museum and Gardens|accessdate=21 September 2015}}</ref> *1997: ''Transforming the Crown: African, Asian and Caribbean Artists in Britain, 1966-1996'', [[Studio Museum in Harlem]], [[Bronx Museum of the Arts]], and Caribbean Cultural Center (Manhattan), New York<ref name="Companion 2002" /><ref>[[Holland Cotter]], [https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/24/arts/art-review-this-realm-of-newcomers-this-england.html?pagewanted=all "ART REVIEW; This Realm of Newcomers, This England"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', 24 October 1997.</ref> *1998: ''Family Histories: Eating with Our Memories, Sleeping with the Ancestors'', [[198 Gallery]], London (solo)<ref name="Companion 2002" /> *1995: ''Time Machine: Ancient Egypt and Contemporary Art'', [[InIVA]] and [[British Museum]], London<ref name="InIVA Time Machine 1995">{{cite web|title=Time Machine: Ancient Egypt and Contemporary Art|url=http://www.iniva.org/exhibitions_projects/1995/time_machine_ancient_egypt_and_contemporary_art|publisher=InIVA|accessdate=21 September 2015}}</ref> *1993: ''Rites of Passage'', [[ICA, London]] (solo) *1992: ''Trophies of Empire'', [[Arnolfini Gallery]], Bristol<ref name="aavad 2006">{{cite web|title=Keegan, Rita - Bibliography and Exhibitions|url=http://aavad.com/artistbibliog.cfm?id=10411|website=African American Visual Artists Database}}</ref> *1992: ''White Noise: Artists Working with Sound'', [[Ikon Gallery]], Birmingham *1991: ''Four X 4'' curated by [[Eddie Chambers (artist)|Eddie Chambers]], Wolverhampton Art Gallery, Wolverhampton<ref name="Four X 4">{{cite book|last1=Chambers|first1=Eddie|title=Four X 4|date=1991|isbn=0951329014|url=http://new.diaspora-artists.net/display_item.php?id=169&table=artefacts&linkphrase=Four+X+4}} Diaspora Artists.</ref> *1991: ''Family Album: An exhibition by Brixton Black Women Artists'', Copyart Resource Centre, London *1990: ''Let the Canvas Come to Life with Dark Faces'', Bluecoat *1985: ''Mirror Reflecting Darkly: Black Women's Art'', Brixton Art Gallery, London<ref name="aavad 2006" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Mirror Reflecting Darkly – Black Womens Art – Womens Work 4|url=http://brixton50.co.uk/mirror-reflecting-darkly/|publisher=Brixton Art Gallery Archive|accessdate=1 December 2015}}</ref> *1983: ''Women's Work'', Brixton Art Gallery, London<ref name="aavad 2006" />
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== *Rita Keegan, [https://data.journalarchives.jisc.ac.uk/britishlibrary/sparerib/view?pubId=P523_344_Issue209PDFP523_344_Issue209_0036_83pdf&terms=%22rita%20keegan%22&tab=date "The Story So Far"], ''[[Spare Rib]]'', February 1990, Issue 209, p. 36. *Rita Keegan, [https://data.journalarchives.jisc.ac.uk/britishlibrary/sparerib/view?pubId=P523_344_Issue197PDFP523_344_Issue197_0044_120pdf&terms=%22rita%20keegan%22&tab=date "Once Upon a Time"], ''Spare Rib'', December–January 1988, Issue 197, p. 44. * Guy Burch; Françoise Dupré (2011). [https://books.google.co.uk/books/about/Brixton_Calling.html?id=JXJmrgEACAAJ&redir_esc=y ''Brixton Calling!: Then & Now: Brixton Art Gallery & the Brixton Artists Collective'']. {{ISBN|978-1-902770-13-0}}.
==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iG2Dosvm2yU "Rita Keegan"] (YouTube video, posted 9 August 2013), SamtheWheels, 2008. * [http://www.calmview.eu/Goldsmiths/CalmView/Record.aspx?src=CalmView.Catalog&id=MAKE%2FIN%2FWOCI Women of Colour Index] archive record at The Women's Art Library at [[Goldsmiths College]], London.
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Keegan, Rita}} [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Black British artists]] [[Category:British women artists]] [[Category:20th-century women artists]] [[Category:San Francisco Art Institute alumni]] [[Category:Archivists]] [[Category:High School of Art and Design alumni]] [[Category:Female archivists]] [[Category:Artists from New York City]]

[[Image:Winter Palace Rotonda1834.jpg|thumb|right|225px|The Rotunda in 1834, by
[[Yefim Tukharinov]].]] The '''Rotunda of the Winter Palace''' in [[St Petersburg]] is a circular hall in the northwest wing of the palace created for Tsar [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]] by the architect [[Auguste de Montferrand]]. Designed in a circular [[Neoclassical architecture|neoclassical]] temple style, it served as an anteroom, [[Vestibule (architecture)|vestibule]] and link between the more public state rooms of the palace and the more intimate rooms used by the Imperial family. The room is [[dome]]d and top lit by an [[oculus]]. The Rotunda was one of the many rooms destroyed by the Winter Palace fire of 1837. It was rebuilt in near-original style, but with the addition of a gallery under the dome. Today, the Rotunda is an exhibition hall of the [[State Hermitage Museum]]. == References == *[http://www.hermitagemuseum.org/html_En/05/hm5_4_2_1_1.html The State Hermitage Museum] retrieved 10 November 2008 [[Image:RotondaWinterPalace.jpg|thumb|175px|left|Plan showing location of the Rotunda within the Winter Palace]] {{The Winter Palace}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rotunda Of The Winter Palace}} [[Category:Hermitage Museum]] [[Category:Auguste de Montferrand buildings and structures]]

{{About|the Royal Mint in the United Kingdom}} {{EngvarB|date=February 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox company | name = The Royal Mint | logo = [[File:The Royal Mint logo.png|200px|alt=Logo of the Royal Mint]] | type = [[Government-owned company]] | predecessor = | successor = | founder = | defunct = | fate = | area_served = United Kingdom & [[British Overseas Territories]] | key_people = Anne Jessopp
{{small|([[Chief executive officer|Chief Executive]])}}{{cite web|title=Chief Executive|url=http://www.royalmint.com/aboutus/chiefexecutive|publisher=The Royal Mint|accessdate=4 January 2018}} | industry = [[Coin]] and medal production | genre = | products = Coins
Medals
Bullion | services = | revenue = {{increase}} £506 million (2017){{cite web|title=The Royal Mint Limited Consolidated Annual Report 2016–17|url=https://www.royalmint.com/globalassets/the-royal-mint/pdf/royal-mint-limited-annual-report-16-17.pdf|publisher=Royal Mint|accessdate=8 December 2017}} | operating_income = {{increase}} £ 14.5 million (2017) | assets = {{increase}} £ 71.9 million (2017) | equity = {{increase}} £ 90.9 million (2017) | owner = [[HM Treasury]] | num_employees = 900+ | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | footnotes = | intl = | foundation = AD {{Start date and age|886}} | location_city = [[Llantrisant]] | location_country = [[Wales]] | location = | locations = | homepage = {{url|www.royalmint.com}} }} The '''Royal Mint''' is a government-owned mint that produces coins for the United Kingdom. Operating under the name ''Royal Mint Ltd,'' the mint is a [[limited company]] that is wholly owned by [[HM Treasury|Her Majesty's Treasury]] and is under an exclusive contract to supply all the nation's coinage. As well as minting circulating coins for use domestically and internationally, the mint also produces [[planchet]]s, [[commemorative coin]]s, various types of [[medal]]s and [[precious metal]] [[bullion]].{{cite web|title=About The Royal Mint|url=http://www.royalmint.com/aboutus/|accessdate=25 August 2015|publisher=The Royal Mint|date=25 August 2015|work=}} The mint exports to an average of 60 countries a year, making up 70% of its total sales.{{Cite web|url=https://www.themanufacturer.com/articles/factory-of-the-month-the-royal-mint/|title=Factory of the month: The Royal Mint|last=|first=|date=7 December 2012|website=|publisher=themanufacturer.com|access-date=13 June 2017}} Formed over 1,100 years ago, the mint was historically part of a series of mints that became centralised to produce coins for the [[Kingdom of England]], all of [[Great Britain]] and eventually most of the [[British Empire]]. The original London mint from which the Royal Mint is the successor, was established in 886 AD and operated within the [[Tower of London]] for approximately 800 years before moving to what is now called [[Royal Mint Court]] where it remained until the 1960s. As Britain followed the rest of the world in [[Decimalisation|decimalising]] its currency, the Mint moved from London to a new {{convert|38|acre}} plant in [[Llantrisant]], [[Wales]] where it has remained since. In 2009 after recommendations for the mint to be privatised the Royal Mint ceased being an executive government agency and became a [[State-owned enterprise|state-owned company]] wholly owned by [[HM Treasury]]. Since then the mint has expanded its business interests by reviving its bullion trade and developing a £9 million visitor centre. == History == === Origin === [[File:Alfred_den_store,_Nordisk_familjebok.png|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Alfred_den_store,_Nordisk_familjebok.png|thumb|150x150px|Coin of [[Alfred the Great]]|alt=Drawing of a coin showing a portrait of Alfred the Great]] The history of coins in [[Great Britain]] can be traced back to the second century BC when they were introduced by [[Celts|Celtic]] tribes from across the [[English Channel]]. The first record of coins being minted in Britain is attributed to [[Kent]]ish tribes such as the [[Cantiaci|Cantii]] who around 80–60 B.C. imitated those of [[Marseille]] through [[casting]] instead of [[Hammered coinage|hammering]].{{Cite web|url=http://coinproject.com/jan/volume1/issue4/volume1-4-2.html|title=Britain's First Coins|last=Rudd|first=Chris|date=|website=|access-date=6 June 2017}} After the [[Roman Empire|Romans]] began their [[Roman conquest of Britain|invasion of Britain]] in AD 43, they set up mints across the land, including in [[London]] which produced [[Roman currency|Roman coins]] for some 40 years before closing. A mint in London reopened briefly in 383 AD until closing swiftly as [[End of Roman rule in Britain|Roman rule in Britain]] came to an end. For the next 200 years no coins appear to have been minted in Britain until the emergence of [[History of Anglo-Saxon England|English kingdoms]] in 650 AD when as many as 30 mints are recorded across Britain with one being established in London.{{cite web|url=http://www.royalmintmuseum.org.uk/history/the-royal-mint-story/index.html|title=The Royal Mint Story|website=Royal Mint|access-date=25 May 2017}} Control of Britain's mints alternated as different tribes battled over territory. In 886 AD [[Alfred the Great]] recaptured London from the [[Danelaw]] and began issuing silver pennies bearing his portrait;{{sfn|Dyer|1986|p=3}} this is regarded as the start of the continuous history of the Royal Mint.{{Cite web|url=https://collections.museumvictoria.com.au/articles/3764|title=The Royal Mint|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[Museums Victoria]]|access-date=6 June 2017}} === 886 to 1805 === [[File:The_Tower_of_London_1647.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:The_Tower_of_London_1647.jpg|left|thumb|300x300px|The [[Tower of London]] in 1647|alt=1847 drawing of the Tower of London on the River Thames]] In 1279, the country's numerous mints were unified under a single system whereby control was centralised to the mint within the [[Tower of London]], mints outside of London were reduced with only a few local and episcopals continuing to operate.{{Cite web|url=http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/r/C207|title=Records of the Royal Mint|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[The National Archive]]|access-date=6 June 2017}} [[Pipe rolls]] detailing the financial records of the London mint show an expenditure of £729 17s 8½d and records of timber bought for workshops. Individual roles at the mint were well established by 1464. The master-worker was charged with hiring engravers and the management of [[moneyer]]s, while the [[Warden of the Mint|mint warden]] was responsible for witnessing the delivery of dies. A specialist mint board was set up in 1472 to enact a 23 February indenture which vested the mint's responsibilities into three main roles; a [[Warden of the Mint|warden]], a [[Master of the Mint|master]] and a [[comptroller]]. In the 16th century having suffering from the effects of the [[Black Death]], mainland [[Europe]] was in the middle of an [[economic expansion]], [[England]] however was suffering with financial difficulty brought on by excessive government spending. By the 1540s wars with [[France]] and [[Scotland]] led [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]] to enact [[The Great Debasement]] which saw the amount of precious metal in coin significantly reduced.{{Cite web|url=http://www.amrcoins.com/information-and-articles/the-testoons-of-henry-viii/|title=The Testoons of Henry VIII|last=|first=|date=|website=AMR Coins|access-date=2 April 2017}} In order to further gather control of the country's currency, [[Dissolution of the Monasteries|monasteries]] were dissolved which effectively ended major coin production outside of London. In 1603, the [[Union of England and Scotland Act 1603|union of Scotland and England]] under King [[James VI and I|James VI]] led to a partial union of both countries' currencies, the [[pound Scots]] and the [[pound sterling]]. Due to Scotland heavily debasing its silver coins, a Scots mark was worth just 13.5d compared to an English mark which was worth 6s 8d. To bridge the difference between the values, unofficial supplementary [[token coin]]s, often made from [[lead]] were made by unauthorised minters across the country. By 1612 there were 3,000 such unlicensed mints producing these tokens, none of whom paying anything towards the [[The Crown|crown]]. ''The Royal Mint'', not wanting to divert manpower away from minting more profitable [[gold]] and [[silver]], hired outside agent [[John Harington, 1st Baron Harington of Exton|Lord Harington]] who under licence started issuing [[copper]] [[Farthing (English coin)|farthings]] in 1613. Private licenses to mint these coins were revoked in 1644 which led traders to resume minting their own supplementary tokens. In 1672 the Royal Mint finally took over the production of copper coinage. ==== Civil War mints ==== [[File:Wenceslas Hollar - Half-crown of Charles I (State 2) 2.jpg|thumb|300x300px|[[Charles I of England|Charles I]] Civil War half-crown|alt=Drawing of the reverse and obverse of a Charles I Civil War half-crown coin]] Prior to the outbreak of the [[English Civil War]], England signed a treaty in 1630 with [[Spain]] which ensured a steady supply of silver [[bullion]] to the [[Tower of London|Tower mint]]. Additional branch mints to aid the one in London were set up including one at [[Aberystwyth Castle]], in [[Wales]]. In 1642 [[parliament]] seized control of the Tower mint and after [[Charles I of England|Charles I]] tried to arrest the [[Five Members]] he was forced to flee London, establishing at least 16 emergency mints across the [[British Isles]] in [[Colchester]], [[Chester]], [[Cork (city)|Cork]], [[Edinburgh]], [[Dublin]], [[Exeter]], [[Salisbury]], parts of [[Cornwall]] including [[Truro]], [[Weymouth, Dorset|Weymouth]], [[Worcester]], [[York]], [[Carlisle, Cumbria|Carlisle]], [[Newark, Peterborough|Newark]], [[Pontefract]] and [[Scarborough, North Yorkshire|Scarborough]] (see also [[siege money]]). After raising the royal standard in [[Nottingham]] marking the beginning of the war, Charles called upon [[Loyalism|loyalist]] mining engineer [[Thomas Bushell (mining engineer)|Thomas Bushell]], the owner of a mint and silver mine in [[Aberystwyth]], to move his operations to the royalist-held [[Shrewsbury]], possibly within in the grounds of [[Shrewsbury Castle]]. The mint there was however short-lived, operating for no more than three months before Charles ordered Bushell to relocate the mint to his headquarters in the royal capital of [[Oxford]]. The new Oxford mint was established on 15 December 1642 in [[New Inn Hall]] at [[University of Oxford|Oxford University]], the present site of [[St Peter's College, Oxford|St. Peter's College]]. There, silver plates and foreign coins were melted down and in some cases just hammered into shape to produce coins quickly. Bushell was appointed the mint's warden and master-worker, where he laboured alongside notable engravers [[Nicholas Briot]], [[Thomas Rawlins]] and [[Nicholas Burghers]], the later of whom being appointed Graver of Seals, Stamps and Medals in 1643. When [[Prince Rupert of the Rhine|Prince Rupert]] took control of Oxford that same year, Bushnell was ordered to move to [[Bristol Castle]] where he continued minting coins until it fell to parliamentary control on 11 September 1645, effectively ending Bushnell's involvement in the civil war mints. In Southern England in November 1642 the king ordered royalist [[Parliament of England|MP]] [[Sir Richard Vyvyan, 1st Baronet|Richard Vyvyan]] to build one or more mints in [[Cornwall]] where he was instructed to mint coins from whatever bullion that could be obtained and deliver it to [[Ralph Hopton, 1st Baron Hopton|Ralph Hopton]], a commander of royalist troops in the region. Vyvyan built a mint in [[Truro]] and became its Master until 1646 when it was captured by [[Roundhead|parliamentarians]]. In nearby [[Exeter]] which had been under control of [[Palace of Westminster|Westminster]] since the beginning of the war, a mint was ordered to be set up after parliament debated the proposal on 8 December 1642. After approval was granted, a mint and moneyers were dispatched on 8 December 1642 to the town which was under constant threat of attack by [[Cavalier|loyalist]] troops. In September 1643 the town was captured by the [[Cornish Royalist Army]] led by [[Maurice of the Palatinate|Prince Maurice]] leading to Vyvyan moving his nearby mint in [[Truro]] to the now recaptured town. The exact location of the mint in [[Exeter]] is unknown, however maps from the time show a street named Old Mint Lane near Friernhay which was to be the site of a [[Great Recoinage of 1696|1696 Recoinage]] mint. Much less is known about the mint's employees with only Richard Vyvyan and clerk Thomas Hawkes recorded.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ceredigion.gov.uk/utilities/action/act_download.cfm?mediaid=29445&langtoken=eng|title=Making a Mint?|last=Morgns|first=Geraint|date=December 1999|work=Country Quest|access-date=17 July 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120831203640/http://www.ceredigion.gov.uk/utilities/action/act_download.cfm?mediaid=29445&langtoken=eng|archive-date=2012-08-31|dead-url=yes}} [[File:Commonwealth Unite 1653 692157.jpg|left|thumb|250x250px|Commonwealth [[Unite (English coin)|Unite]] 1653 |alt=Photo of a 1653 gold Unite coin]] [[File:England, Commonwealth, Cromwelltaler 1658, CNG.jpg|thumb|250x250px|1658 Cromwell [[Crown (English coin)|Crown]]|left|alt=Photo of a 1658 silver Crown coin featuring Oliver Cromwell]]Following Charles I's execution in 1649, the newly formed [[Commonwealth of England]] established its own set of coins which for the first time used [[English language|English]] rather than [[Latin]] and were plainly designed compared to those previously issued under the [[Monarchy of the United Kingdom|monarchy]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.numismaster.com/ta/numis/Article.jsp?ad=article&ArticleId=28446|title=Cromwell Put is Portrait on Coins|last=Julian|first=R.W.|date=23 January 2017|website=numismaster.com|access-date=17 July 2017}} The government invited French engineer [[Peter Blondeau]] who worked at the [[Monnaie de Paris|Paris mint]] to come to London in 1649 in hope of modernising the country's minting process. In France [[Hammered coinage|hammer stuck coins]] had been banned from the [[Monnaie de Paris|Paris Mint]] since 1639 and replaced with [[Milled coinage|milled]] coinage.{{sfn|Allen|2009|p=282}} After arriving, it wasn't until 9 May 1651 that his testing began in [[Drury House]], having first required permission from parliament. He initially produced milled silver [[Pattern coin|pattern pieces]] of [[Half crown (British coin)|halfcrowns]], [[Shilling (English coin)|shillings]] and [[Sixpence (British coin)|sixpences]] however rival moneyers favouring hammer stuck coins continued using the old hammering method. In 1656 [[Lord Protector]] [[Oliver Cromwell]] ordered engraver [[Thomas Simon]] to cut a series of dies featuring his [[Bust (sculpture)|bust]] and for them to be minted using the new milled method. Few of Cromwell's coins entered circulation with Cromwell himself dying in 1658 and the Commonwealth collapsing two year later. Without Cromwell's backing of milled coinage, [[Peter Blondeau]] returned to France leaving England to continue minting hammer struck coins. [[File:Sir_Isaac_Newton_1702.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Sir_Isaac_Newton_1702.jpg|thumb|249x249px|[[Isaac Newton]] in 1702|alt=Portrait of Isaac Newton from 1702]] In 1662, after previous attempts to introduce [[milled coinage]] into Britain had failed, the restored monarch [[Charles II of England|Charles II]] recalled [[Peter Blondeau]] to establish a permanent machine-made coinage.{{harvp|Linecar|1985|pages=88–98}}.{{sfn|Glyn|2010|p=888}} Despite the introduction of the newer, milled coins, like the old [[Hammered coinage|hammered coins]] they suffered heavily from counterfeiting and [[Methods of coin debasement|clipping]]. To combat this the text ''Decus et tutamen'' (An ornament and a safeguard) was added to some coin rims.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.es/books?id=eq20AAAAIAAJ&q=the+origin+of+the+process+is+attributed+to+%5B%5BIsaac+Newton%5D%5D,+after+being+appointed+%5B%5BMaster+of+the+Mint%5D%5D+%28charge+he+held&dq=the+origin+of+the+process+is+attributed+to+%5B%5BIsaac+Newton%5D%5D,+after+being+appointed+%5B%5BMaster+of+the+Mint%5D%5D+%28charge+he+held&hl=ca&sa=X&ei=mGS-VKGZKYOqU7HiguAH&ved=0CCEQ6AEwAA|title=Economic Progress Report|publisher=Information Division of the Treasury.|year=1986|author=Great Britain. Treasury. Information Division}} Following the [[Glorious Revolution]] of 1688, which saw the ousting of [[James II of England|James II]] from power, parliament took over control of the mint from the [[The Crown|Crown]] which had up until then allowed the mint to act as an independent body producing coins on behalf of the government. Under the patronage of [[Charles Montagu, 1st Earl of Halifax]], [[Isaac Newton]] became the mint's [[Warden of the Mint|warden]] in 1696. His role, intended to be a [[sinecure]], was taken seriously by Newton, who went about trying to combat the country's growing problems with counterfeiting. By this time, forgeries accounted for 10% of the country's coinage, [[Methods of coin debasement|clipping]] was commonplace and the value of silver in coins had surpassed their [[face value]]. [[William III of England|King William III]] initiated the [[Great Recoinage of 1696]] whereby all coins were removed from circulation and enacted the [[Coin Act 1696]] making it [[high treason]] to own or possess [[counterfeit]]ing equipment. Satellite mints to aid in the re-coinage were established in [[Bristol]], [[Chester]], [[Exeter]], [[Norwich]], and [[York]], with returned coins being valued by weight, not [[face value]]. The [[Acts of Union 1707]] united England and Scotland into one country, leading London to take over production of Scotland's currency and thus replacing Scotland's [[Pound Scots]] with the English [[Pound sterling|Pound Sterling]] which caused the Edinburgh mint to eventually close on 4 August 1710. As [[British Empire|Britain's empire]] continued to expand, so to was the need to supply its coinage. This along with the need for new mint machinery and cramped conditions within the [[Tower of London]], led to plans for the mint to move to nearby [[East Smithfield]]. === 1805 to 1967 === ==== Tower Hill ==== {{further information|Royal Mint Court}} [[File:The Royal Mint, London (378803870).jpg|alt=Exterior of the Johnson Smirke Building in London|left|thumb|280x280px|Johnson Smirke Building in 2007]] Located opposite from the Tower of London on Tower Hill, the new purpose-built mint began construction in 1805 and was completed by 1809. However it was not until 1812 that the move became official, when keys from the old mint were ceremoniously delivered to the Constable of the Tower.{{Cite web|url=http://www.royalmintmuseum.org.uk/history/the-royal-mint-story/tower-hill/index.html|title=Tower Hill|last=|first=|date=|website=Royal Mint|access-date=28 April 2017}} Facing the front of the site stood the Johnson Smirke Building whose [[namesake]] comes from its designer James Johnson and builder [[Robert Smirke (architect)|Robert Smirke]]. This building was flanked on both sides by gatehouses behind which another building housed the mint's new machinery. A number of other smaller buildings were also erected which housed mint officers and staff members. The entire site was protected by a boundary wall which was patrolled by the Royal Mint's military guard. By 1856, the mint was beginning to prove inefficient, suffering from irregularities in minted coins' fineness and weight. Instructed by [[Prime Minister]] [[Henry John Temple, 3rd Viscount Palmerston|Lord Palmerston]], the Master of the Mint [[Thomas Graham (chemist)|Thomas Graham]] was informed that unless the mint could raise its standards and become more economical it would be broken up and placed under management by contractors. Graham sought advice from German chemist [[August Wilhelm von Hofmann]] who in turn recommended his student [[George Frederick Ansell]] as being able to resolve the mint's issues. In a letter to the treasury dated 29 October 1856, Ansell was put forward as candidate and subsequently was awarded the role of temporary clerk on 12 November 1856 with a £120 a year salary.{{sfn|Ansell|1870|p=}} Upon taking office, Ansell discovered that the weighing of metals at the mint was extremely loose. At the mint it had been the custom to weigh silver to within 0.5 ounces and gold to a pennyweight (0.05 ounces), however these standards meant losses were being made from overvalued metals. In one such case Ansell delivered 7920.00 ounces of gold to the mint where it was weighed by an official at 7918.15 ounces, a difference of 1.85 ounces. Requesting a second weighing on more accurate scale, the bullion was certified to weigh 7919.98 ounces, far closer to the previous measurement which was off by 960 [[Grain (unit)|grains]]. To increase the accuracy of weights, more precise weighing equipment was ordered and specifications were revised to 0.10 ounce for silver and gold to 0.01oz. Between 1856 and 1866 the old scales were gradually removed and replaced with ones made by Messrs. De Grave, Short, and Fanner; winners of a [[1862 International Exhibition]] prize award for work relating to [[Weighing scale|balances]].{{sfn|Ansell|1870|p=}} Another observation Ansell made was the loss of gold during the manufacturing process. He found that 15-20 ounces could be recovered through the sweep, that is the leftover burnt rubbish from the minting process which was often left in open boxes for many months before being removed. Wanting to account for every particle, he hypothesised that because the [[Conservation of mass]] meant it was physically impossible for gold to just disappear he put down the lost weight to a combination of [[oil]], [[dust]] and different types of foreign matter amongst the gold. In 1859, the Royal Mint rejected a batch of gold that was found to be too brittle for the minting of gold sovereigns. Analysis revealed the presence of small amounts of [[antimony]], [[arsenic]] and [[lead]]. With Ansell's background in [[chemistry]], he persuaded the Royal Mint to allow him to experiment with the [[alloy]] and was ultimately able to produce 167,539 gold [[Sovereign (British coin)|sovereigns]].{{cite web|url=http://goldsovereignexpert.com/coins/47/1859-Ansell-Gold-Sovereign/|title=1859 'Ansell' Sovereign|ref=harv|accessdate=8 February 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160215090816/http://goldsovereignexpert.com/coins/47/1859-Ansell-Gold-Sovereign/|archivedate=15 February 2016|df=dmy-all}} On a second occasion in 1868, it was again discovered that gold coins, this time totalling £500,000 worth, were being produced with inferior gold. Although the standard practise at the mint was for rejected coins (known as brockages) to be melted down, many entered general circulation and the mint was forced to return thousands of ounces of gold to the [[Bank of England]]. Although Ansell offered to re-melt the substandard coins, his offer was rejected causing a row between him and senior mint chiefs which ultimately led to him being removed from his position at the mint.W. P. Courtney, rev. Robert Brown, [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/571 "Ansell, George Frederick (1826–1880)"], ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, 2004. Accessed 10 February 2017. [[File:Gold_Melting_at_the_Royal_Mint_1800s.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Gold_Melting_at_the_Royal_Mint_1800s.jpg|thumb|Gold Melting Process (1870)|alt=Drawing of workers melting gold in 1870]] ==== Royal Mint Refinery ==== After relocating to its new home on Tower Hill, the Mint came under increased scrutiny of how it dealt with unrefined gold that had entered the country. Initially the [[Master of the Mint]] was responsible for overseeing the practise since the position's inception in the 1300s, however the refinery process proved too costly and suffered from a lack of accountability from the master. A [[Royal Commission]] later set up in 1848 to address these issues gave recommendation for the refinery process to be [[Outsourcing|outsourced]] to another external agency thereby removing the refining process from the mint's responsibilities. The opportunity to handle in Mint's refinery was taken up by [[Sir Anthony de Rothschild, 1st Baronet|Anthony de Rothschild]], a descendant of the [[Rothschild family]] and heir to the [[Multinational corporation|multinational]] [[investment banking]] company [[N M Rothschild & Sons]]. Rothschild secured a lease from the government in January 1852, purchasing equipment and a premise adjacent to the Royal Mint on 19 Royal Mint Street under the name of ''Royal Mint Refinery''. ==== Colonial Expansion ==== [[File:The Royal Mint, Sydney 1888.jpg|left|thumb|300x300px|Royal Mint, Sydney in 1888|alt=Drawing of Sydney Royal Mint building in 1888]] As Britain's influence as a [[Great power|world power]] expanded, with colonies being established abroad, a greater need for currency led to the Royal Mint opening satellite branches of itself overseas. In [[Australia]], the local Legislative Council petitioned the UK government to establish a branch of the Royal Mint in [[Sydney]] ([[Sydney Mint]]) after prospector [[Edward Hargraves]] discovered gold in [[Ophir, New South Wales|Ophir]], [[New South Wales]] in 1851. The petitioned gain [[royal assent]] in 1853 and plans were made by the Deputy Master of the Royal Mint in London to open the Royal Mint's first overseas branch within the colony. The Royal Mint's Superintendent of Coining travelled to Australia to oversee its establishment on [[Macquarie Street, Sydney|Macquarie Street]] within the southern wing of [[Sydney Hospital]] where it opened in 1854. Its success led to the opening of [[Melbourne Mint]] on 2 June 1872 which cost £368,350 and [[Perth Mint]] which opened on 20 June 1899. In 1926 after operating for 72 years, the [[Sydney Mint]] closed due to its inferior technology and capabilities being superseded by those in Melbourne and Perth. After [[Federation of Australia|Australia was federalised]] in 1901, Great Britain continued to own the mints to as late as 1 July 1970, when they became statutory authorities of the [[Government of Western Australia]]. In [[Canada]], which had been under [[Canada under British rule|British rule]] since 1763, British coins circulated alongside those of other nations until 1858 when London started producing coins for the newly established [[Canadian dollar]]. As Canada developed, in 1890 calls were made for a mint to be built in [[Ottawa]] to facilitate the country's gold mines. The new mint opened on 2 January 1908 by [[Albert Grey, 4th Earl Grey|Lord Grey]] producing coins for circulation including [[Ottawa Mint sovereign|Ottawa Mint sovereigns.]] In 1931 under the [[Statute of Westminster 1931|Statute of Westminster]], the mint came under the control on the [[Government of Canada]] and subsequently renamed the [[Royal Canadian Mint]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.ontarioplaques.com/Plaques/Plaque_Ottawa30.html|title=Ontario's Historical Plaques|last=|first=|date=|website=ontarioplaques.com|access-date=2 July 2017}}[[File:HongKong-1Dollar-1867.jpg|thumb|Hong Kong silver dollar (1867)|alt=Obverse and reverse of an 1867 silver Hong Kong dollar coin]]A fifth branch of the Royal Mint was established in [[Mumbai]] (Bombay), [[India]] on 21 December 1917 as part of a wartime effort. It struck sovereign from 15 Aug 1918 til 22 Apr 1919. before closing in May 1919.{{sfn|Michael|2016|p=1130}}{{Cite web|url=http://goldsovereign.in/the-india-story/|title=The History of the Indian Sovereign|last=|first=|date=|website=goldsovereign.in|access-date=22 July 2017}} A sixth and final overseas mint was established in the [[Union of South Africa]] in [[Pretoria]] on 1 January 1923, producing £83,114,575 worth of [[Sovereign (British coin)|sovereigns]] of its lifetime. As South Africa began cutting ties with Britain, the mint closed on 30 June 1941 only to be later reopened as the [[South African Mint]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.southcapecoins.co.za/news/the-history-of-the-south-african-mint/|title=The History of the South African Mint|last=|first=|date=|website=southcapecoins.co.za|access-date=22 July 2017}} Although just six mints were officially controlled by London's Royal Mint, many more independent mints were set up to facilitate parts of the [[British Empire]]. In [[New Westminster]], [[British Columbia]] the [[British Columbia gold rushes]] led to a mint being set up in 1862 under Governor [[James Douglas (governor)|James Douglas]] where it produced a few gold and silver coins before being shut down in 1862 to aid the city of [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]] in becoming the regions [[Capital city|provincial capital]].{{sfn|Hainsworth|2005|p=148}} On 26 February 1864 an Order of Council requested for the founding of independent mint ([[Hong Kong Mint]]) in [[British Hong Kong]] to issue silver and bronze coins.{{Cite web|url=http://www.lcsd.gov.hk/ce/Museum/History/en_US/web/mh/publications/spa_pspecial_02_01.html|title=Hong Kong Currency|last=|first=|date=|website=[[Leisure and Cultural Services Department]]|access-date=22 July 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/r/C11029|title=Royal Mint: Branch Mints |last=|first=|date=|publisher=[[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|The National Archives]]|access-date=22 July 2017}} This mint was short lived however due to its coins being heavy debasement causing significant losses. The site was sold to [[History of Jardine, Matheson & Co.|Jardine Matheson]] in 1868 and the mint machinery sold to the Japanese Mint in [[Osaka]].{{sfn|Ingham|2007|p=70}} [[New Zealand]]'s [[New Zealand one-dollar coin|$1]] and [[New Zealand two-dollar coin|$2]] coins are minted by the Royal Mint in the United Kingdom. The 10 cent, 20 cent and 50 cent coins are minted by the Royal Canadian Mint. Other mints the Bank has used over time include: the Royal Australian Mint, Norwegian Mint and the South African Mint Company. The F4 Coin mintings data has details about the number and value of coin mintages.{{Cite web|url=http://www.rbnz.govt.nz/notes-and-coins/coins/history-of-new-zealand-coinage|title=The history of coins in New Zealand|last=|first=|date=|publisher=[[Reserve Bank of New Zealand]]|access-date=22 July 2017}} ==== 1914 to 1967 ==== In 1914 as war broke out in Europe, [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]] [[David Lloyd George]] instructed for gold coins to be removed from circulation so as to help pay for the war effort. The government started to issue £1 and 10 shilling treasury notes as replacement paving the way for Britain leaving the gold standard in 1931. [[File:Royal Mint Reducing Machine.jpg|thumb|250x250px|Engraving room at the Royal Mint in 1934|alt=Engraving room at the Royal Mint in 1934]] From 1928, the [[Irish Free State]] (later Republic of Ireland) issued its own [[Coins of the Republic of Ireland|coins]]. These were produced by the Royal Mint until Ireland established its own [[Currency Centre]] in Dublin in 1978. During World War II the Mint played an important role in ensuring that people were paid for their services with [[hard currency]] rather than banknotes. Under [[Operation Bernhard]], the [[Nazi Germany|Nazis]] planned to collapse the [[Economy of the United Kingdom|British economy]] by flooding the country with forged notes leading the [[Bank of England]] to stop issuing banknotes of £10 and above. To meet these demands the Mint doubled its output so that by 1943 it was minting around 700 million coins a year despite being under constant threat of being bombed. The Deputy Master of the Mint John Craig recognised the dangers to the Mint, introduced a number of measures to ensure the Mint could continue to operate in the event of a disaster. Craig added emergency water supplies, reinforced the Mint's basement to act as an [[air-raid shelter]] and even accepted employment of women for the first time. For most of the war the mint managed to escape the destruction of [[the Blitz]] until December 1940 when three members of staff were killed in an [[Airstrike|air-raid]]. Around the same time an auxiliary mint was set up at [[Pinewood Studios]] which had been requisitioned for the war effort. Staff and machinery from Tower Hill were moved to the site in [[Buckinghamshire]] where it started production in June 1941 and operated for the duration of the war.{{sfn|Beardon|2013|p=177}}{{sfn|Challis|1992|p=579}} Over the course of the war the Royal Mint was hit on several different occasions and at one point was put out of commission for three weeks. As technology changed with the introduction of electricity and demand continuing to grow, the process of rebuilding continued so that by the 1960s little of the original mint remained, apart from Smirke's 1809 building and its gatehouses at the front. On 1 March 1966 the government announced its intention for the pound to be [[Decimalisation|decimalised]] which would require a large-scale withdrawal and minting of millions of new coins, this, as well as commitments to overseas customers, meant the mint was to be faced with a heavy workload. Lack of space at the mint and with [[Decimal Day]] looming it became apparent that the mint needed to again relocate to a larger site. With a degree of urgency plans were made in April 1967 for a new site to be built outside of London, although over twenty sites were considered{{Cite web|url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1970/mar/26/royal-mint#column_1661|title=Royal Mint|last=Pearson|first=Arthur|date=26 March 1970|website=[[Hansard]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090717050847/http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1970/mar/26/royal-mint#column_1661|archive-date=2009-07-17|dead-url=yes|access-date=28 April 2017}} the small [[Wales|Welsh]] town of [[Llantrisant]] located {{convert|10|mi|km|spell=in}} north-west of [[Cardiff]] was chosen{{Cite web|url=http://www.royalmint.com/discover/decimalisation/a-new-royal-mint|title=A New Royal Mint|last=|first=|date=|website=The Royal Mint|access-date=28 April 2017}} Up until now improvements at the Tower Hill mint had cost £800,000.{{citation needed|date=November 2018}} === 1967 to present === ==== Move to Wales ==== [[File:The Royal Mint, Llantrisant.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:The Royal Mint, Llantrisant.jpg|thumb|Royal Mint in [[Llantrisant]]|alt=Exterior of the Royal Mint building located in Llantrisant, Wales|250x250px]] Work on the new mint began in August 1967 with the construction of a [[Planchet|blank]] treatment plant and plant for striking. This first phase of the mint was officially opened on 17 December 1968 by the royal attendance of [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]], [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|Prince Philip]] and their son [[Charles, Prince of Wales|Prince Charles]]. Originally there were fears that the Royal family would face protests because of the [[Investiture of the Prince of Wales|Investiture of Prince Charles]] as the [[Prince of Wales]]; however, such protests failed to materialise.{{cite AV media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gmyFMW4-DU8|title=Queen Opens New Mint (1968)|publisher=[[Pathé News]]|access-date=28 April 2017}} The second phase of construction began in 1973 and included the addition of a means to mint coins from virgin metals completing the full minting process. Upon completion the final cost for the land, buildings and plant came to £8 million.{{Cite web|url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/written_answers/1970/mar/17/royal-mint-move#S5CV0798P0_19700317_CWA_14|title=Royal Mint (Move)|last=Taverne|first=Dick|date=17 March 1970|website=[[Hansard]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090717050720/http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/written_answers/1970/mar/17/royal-mint-move#S5CV0798P0_19700317_CWA_14|archive-date=2009-07-17|dead-url=yes|access-date=28 April 2017}} Coin minting and production gradually shifted to the new site over the next seven years until the last coin, a gold sovereign, was struck in London in November 1975. In an attempt to consolidate all previous coin-related acts, the ''[[Coinage Act 1971|Coinage Act of 1971]]'' was passed, which among other things effectively abolished the individual role of [[Master of the Mint]]. Under this act, the [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]] took over the role, with a Deputy Master being appointed by the [[HM Treasury|Treasury]] to exercise all the powers and duties of the Master within the mint. ==== Financial Difficulties ==== After moving to Wales, the mint struggled to become profitable as the Western world fell into a [[1973–75 recession|deep recession]] during the early 1970s. To combat a rising national debt, the mint was established as a [[trading fund]] on 1 April 1975 which required it to become self-financing. This measure proved successful and the mint started to become profitable through heavy exports.To allow for more financial freedom and better management the mint became an Executive Agency in April 1990.{{Cite web|url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/written_answers/1990/apr/02/royal-mint#S6CV0170P0_19900402_CWA_45|title=HC Deb 02 April 1990 vol 170 cc390-1W|last=|first=|date=|website=Hansard|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090710034211/http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/written_answers/1990/apr/02/royal-mint#S6CV0170P0_19900402_CWA_45|archive-date=2009-07-10|dead-url=yes|access-date=30 May 2017}} During the [[Financial crisis of 2007–2008|2008 global financial crisis]], a [[2008 United Kingdom bank rescue package|rescue package]] costing £500 billion was announced to help stabilise Britain's banking system. This led to fear that the government would attempt to finance the cost by selling off state-owned organisations. In a 2009 pre-budget report the [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]], [[Alistair Darling]] stated that the treasury would "explore the potential benefits of alternative future models for the Royal Mint".{{Cite news|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/business/business-news/privatisation-royal-mint-llantrisant-rolls-2118375|title=Privatisation of Royal Mint at Llantrisant rolls closer|last=Blake|first=Aled|date=17 March 2009|work=[[Wales Online]]|access-date=3 June 2017}} A month later in his [[2009 United Kingdom budget]] he recommended that the mint be made a company with a view of it being sold.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2009/apr/22/budget-public-sector-jobs-risk|title=Budget 2009: Thousands of public sector jobs at risk|last=Bawden|first=Anna|date=22 April 2009|work=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=22 April 2017}} The decision was met with outrage by unions and opposition parties in parliament who called it the "selling off the family silver" and that it would result in jobs losses. In contrast, the chief executive of the mint Andrew Stafford welcomed the decision stating that it would lead to further growth and secure the future of the business.{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/8011331.stm|title=Royal Mint privatisation closer|last=|first=|date=21 April 2009|work=[[BBC News]]|access-date=2 June 2017}} On 31 December 2009, rather than being fully privatised, the mint ceased to be an [[executive agency]] and its assets vested in a [[limited company]], ''Royal Mint Ltd''. The owner of the new company became The Royal Mint trading fund, which itself continued to be owned by [[HM Treasury]]. As its sole shareholder the mint pays an annual dividend of £4 million to treasury with the remaining profits being reinvested into the mint.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/jul/24/royal-mint-makes-mint|title=Royal Mint Makes a Mint … Again|last=Kollewe|first=Julia|date=24 July 2015|work=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=2 June 2017}} In 2015 [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]] [[George Osborne]] announced a £20 billion [[Privatization|privatisation]] drive to raise funds with the ''Royal Mint'' being up for sale alongside other institutions including the [[Met Office]] and [[Companies House]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.ft.com/content/34b153b6-75e9-11e6-bf48-b372cdb1043a|title=Green Investment Bank bidders ready final offer|last=Pickard, Plimmer|first=Jim, Gill|date=11 September 2016|work=[[Financial Times]]|access-date=3 June 2017}} ==== Revival ==== With its new found financial freedom the Mint begun diversifying their product range through expanding to offer items outside their usual coin-related merchandise. By the early 2000s the Mint was selling different types of jewellery, commemorative plates and figurines,{{Cite web|url=http://www.royalmint.com/~/media/Files/AnnualReports/ar200102.pdf|title=Royal Mint Annual Report 2001-02|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Royal Mint|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170613074520/http://www.royalmint.com/~/media/Files/AnnualReports/ar200102.pdf|archive-date=2017-06-13|dead-url=yes|access-date=1 July 2017}} eventually creating its own ''Royal Mint Classics'' range of collectable goods. This part of the business proved popular in attracting new customers however suffered from poor product development. Example of its products included a [[hip flask]] with an embedded [[Two pounds (British coin)|£2 coin]], an [[Edinburgh Crystal]] clock combined with a [[Five pounds (British coin)|millennium Crown]], and a [[Wedgwood]] plate featuring [[Britannia]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.royalmint.com/~/media/Files/AnnualReports/ar19992000.pdf|title=Royal Mint Annual Report 1999 -2000|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Royal Mint|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160331181932/http://www.royalmint.com/~/media/Files/AnnualReports/ar19992000.pdf|archive-date=2016-03-31|dead-url=yes|access-date=1 July 2017}} In 2007 the Mint decided to resume its focus on coins, downsizing non-coin related business and discontinuing its Classics range.{{Cite web|url=http://www.royalmint.com/~/media/Files/AnnualReports/ar200708.pdf|title=The Royal Mint Annual Report 2007-08|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Royal Mint|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160330004630/http://www.royalmint.com/~/media/Files/AnnualReports/ar200708.pdf|archive-date=2016-03-30|dead-url=yes|access-date=1 July 2017}} ==== 2012 London Olympics ==== [[File:As close as I'm going to get to an Olympic gold medal (7654484286).jpg|thumb|2012 Olympic Medal made by the Mint|alt=Photo of 2012 gold Olympic medals]] After London was selected to host the [[2012 Summer Olympics|2012 Summer Olympic Games]], the Royal Mint successfully won its bid to manufacture the games' [[Olympic medal|Olympic and Paralympic medals]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/london-olympics-business/8207463/London-2012-Olympics-Royal-Mint-wins-contract-to-make-medals.html|title=London 2012 Olympics: Royal Mint wins contract to make medals|last=Ruddick|first=Graham|date=16 December 2017|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|access-date=2 July 2017}} 4,700 gold, sliver and bronze medals were produced by the Mint with each medal being struck 15 times with 900 tonnes of force.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-15478810|title=London 2012: Olympic medals go into production in Wales|last=Hume|first=Colette|date=27 October 2011|work=[[BBC News]]|access-date=2 July 2017}} {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="4" |Olympic Medal Specifications{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/anthonydemarco/2012/07/26/a-closer-look-at-the-olympic-gold-medal/#22fe55756d27|title=London's Olympic Gold Medal Worth The Most In The History Of The Games|last=DeMarco|first=Anthony|date=26 July 2012|work=[[Forbes]]|access-date=2 July 2017}} |- ! !Gold Medal !Silver Medal !Bronze Medal |- !Weight |412g |412g |357g |- !Composition |1.34% Gold 93% Silver 6% Copper |93% Silver 7% Copper |97% Copper 2.5% Zinc 0.5% Tin |} In addition to securing the medal product contract, the mint held a competition to design a series of commemorative [[Fifty pence (British coin)|fifty pence coins]] that would enter general circulation prior to the event. The Mint received over 30,000 entries with a further 17,000 from a children's competition on [[Blue Peter]]. In all, a total of 29 designs featuring a sport were selected by the Mint, with the youngest designer being just 9 years old.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-11527266|title=London 2012 Olympic 50p coins go into circulation|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=1 July 2017|publisher=[[BBC]]}} A £2 coin commemorating London's handover to Rio was also released in 2012. ==== The Royal Mint Experience ==== In April 2014 the mint announced plans for the development of a visitor centre in Llantrisant where members of the public could take part in a guided tour of the facility and learn about the mint's history. The development's contract, estimated to be worth £7.7 million was awarded to construction firm ISG and design consultant Mather & Co who had previously designed the [[Norwegian Olympic Museum]], as well as a handful of visitor attractions for sporting clubs including [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea F.C]], [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City F.C]], [[FC Porto]] and the [[South Africa national rugby union team|Springboks]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/business/business-news/royal-mint-appoints-design-consultancy-9034558|title=The Royal Mint appoints design consultancy for its £7.5m interactive museum|last=Barry|first=Sion|date=13 April 2015|work=[[Wales Online]]|access-date=6 July 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.matherandco.com/work/|title=Mather & Co - Our Work|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=matherandco.com|access-date=6 July 2017}} To fund the development, a grant of £2.3 million was provided by the [[Welsh Government]] towards the attraction which aimed to attract 200,000 visitors a year to the area.{{Cite web|url=http://www.royalmint.com/aboutus/news/the-royal-mint-announces-plans-for-first-visitor-centre|title=The Royal Mint announces plans for first visitor centre|last=|first=|date=24 April 2014|website=The Royal Mint|access-date=28 April 2017}} By May 2016, two years after its announcement the now named ''Royal Mint Experience'' opened to the public at a final cost of £9 million. Included in the visitor centre an interactive museum, a view onto the factory floor, an education centre and a press whereby visitors can strike their own souvenir [[One pound (British coin)|£1 coin]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/whats-on/family-kids-news/everything-you-need-know-royal-11344054|title=Everything you need to know about The Royal Mint Experience|last=Doran|first=Lorna|date=17 May 2016|website=Wales Online|access-date=28 April 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/saving/article-4172128/How-UK-coins-Royal-Mint-visit.html|title=Ever wondered how your coins are made? LEE BOYCE takes a trip to the Royal Mint in Wales to find out (and discovers they are actually pickled...)|last=Boyce|first=Lee|date=31 January 2017|website=This is Money|access-date=28 April 2017}} On display at the centre are more than 80,000 artefacts,{{Cite web|url=https://www.designweek.co.uk/issues/november-2014/royal-mint-seeks-exhibition-designers-as-visitor-centre-plans-take-shape/|title=Royal Mint seeks exhibition designers as visitor centre plans take shape|last=Montgomery|first=Angus|date=17 November 2014|website=|publisher=Design Week 30|access-date=6 July 2017}} including [[Olympic medal]]s, a pattern coin of [[Edward VIII]], a [[Reducing Machine|Janvier reducing machine]] and a selection of [[trial plate]]s. ==== Recent Events ==== In the same month the mint took in 48 tonnes of silver recovered from the shipwreck of the [[SS Gairsoppa]] which was used to produce limited edition coins.{{Cite news|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/royal-mint-takes-delivery-48-6916447|title=Royal Mint takes delivery of 48 tonnes of silver salvaged from site of WWII shipwreck|last=Evans|first=Carrie|date=4 April 2014|work=Wales Online|access-date=7 June 2017}} In 2015, after nearly 50 years, the mint began producing its own line of [[bullion]] bars and [[Bullion coin|coins]] under its revived ''Royal Mint Refinery'' brand. Then in 2016, the mint announced plans for [[Royal Mint Gold]] (RMG), a [[digital gold currency]] that uses [[blockchain]] to trade and invest in [[gold]]. Operated by [[CME Group]], the technology is to be created by technology companies [[AlphaPoint]] and [[BitGo]].{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-blockchain-gold-idUKKBN17D2RL|title=CME Group, Royal Mint test blockchain-based gold trading platform|date=11 April 2017|publisher=[[Reuters]]|last1=Anna|first1=Irrera|accessdate=13 June 2017}} The system currency which was due to launch in 2017 will be on the [[gold standard]], whereby one RMG token equates to 1 gram of physical gold held within in a Royal Mint vault. Up to $1 billion worth of RMG is set to be issued by the mint.{{cite news|url=http://www.coindesk.com/consensus-2017-cme-group-uk-royal-mint-detail-plans-blockchain-gold/|title=Consensus 2017: CME Group, UK Royal Mint Detail Plans for Blockchain Gold|date=23 May 2017|publisher=[[CoinDesk]]|last1=Castor|first1=Amy|accessdate=13 June 2017}} == Operations == === Coin production === As the sole body responsible for minting [[legal tender]] coins in the United Kingdom under contract from [[HM Treasury]], the mint produces all of the country's physical currency apart from banknotes which are printed by the [[Bank of England]]. On average it produces 2 billion [[pound sterling]] coins struck for general circulation every year with an estimated 28 billion pieces circulating altogether. Outside of the UK, the mint provides services to over 60 different countries including New Zealand and many [[Caribbean]] nations in the form of producing national currencies or supplying ready to strike [[planchet]]s. In 2015 it was estimated that 2.4 billion coins were minted for overseas countries outweighing that of domestic coinage and providing over 60% of the mint's revenue from circulating currencies. The sale of commemorative coins also form part of the mint's operations with coins of varying quality and made of different precious metals released yearly for the collector's market. {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="4" |Coins minted (billion) |- ! !2015{{Cite web|url=http://www.royalmint.com/~/media/Files/AnnualReports/ar_2015_2016.pdf|title=The Royal Mint Limited Annual Report 2015-16|last=|first=|date=|website=The Royal Mint|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170613110919/http://www.royalmint.com/~/media/Files/AnnualReports/ar_2015_2016.pdf|archive-date=2017-06-13|dead-url=yes|access-date=30 April 2017}} !2014 !2013{{Cite web|url=http://www.royalmint.com/~/media/Files/AnnualReports/ar_2014_2015.pdf|title=The Royal Mint Limited Annual Report 2014-15|last=|first=|date=|website=The Royal Mint|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170613080822/http://www.royalmint.com/~/media/Files/AnnualReports/ar_2014_2015.pdf|archive-date=2017-06-13|dead-url=yes|access-date=30 April 2017}} |- |United Kingdom |2.007 |2.384 |1.996 |- |International |2.4 |2.2 |2.0 |} === Bullion === [[File:Royal Mint Refinery Logo.svg|thumb|150x150px|Royal Mint Refinery Seal|alt=Seal of the Royal Mint Refinery]]Another important operation performed by the mint which contributes to half the mint's revenue is the sale of [[bullion]] to investors or general members of the public in the form of [[Gold bar|bars]] or [[Bullion coin|coins]]. Historically the mint has refined its own metal, however under the advice of an 1848 Royal Commission the process was separated with the independent ''Royal Mint Refinery'' being purchased and operated by [[Sir Anthony de Rothschild, 1st Baronet|Anthony de Rothschild]] in 1852. The [[Rothschild family|Rothschild]] family continued the refinery's management until it was sold to [[Engelhard]] in 1967, a year later the Royal Mint relocated to Wales and ceased their bullion bar interests until reviving the brand in 2015. Bullion bars produced by the mint are stamped with the original Royal Mint Refinery emblem and come in a range of different sizes.{{Cite web|url=http://blog.royalmint.com/gold-bars-royal-mint-refinery/|title=Gold bars now available from The Royal Mint|last=Oliver|first=Dan|date=21 January 2015|website=The Royal Mint|access-date=29 April 2017}} {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="9" |Bullion bars |- !Metal !Fineness ! colspan="7" |Weights |- |[[Silver]] |999 | colspan="4" |n/a |100g |500g |1 kg |- |[[Gold]] |999.9 |1g |5g |10g |1oz |100g |500g |1 kg |- |[[Platinum]] |999.5 | colspan="3" |n/a |1oz |100g |500g |1 kg |}Minting of bullion coins began in 1957 to meet a demand for authentic [[Sovereign (British coin)|sovereign coins]] which suffered from heavy counterfeiting. Coins were released almost every year alongside [[Proof coinage|proof]] versions up to 1982 when production was discontinued. In 1987 the mint started to produce a new type of bullion coin, the 1oz [[Britannia (coin)|Britannia]] coin which was gold and had a face value of £100. A silver version with a face value of £2 was also released in 1997. Production of the previously discontinued sovereign and half sovereigns resumed in 2000. In 2014 a lunar coin series begun being minted annually in celebration of [[Lunar New Year]] and in 2016 a series featuring [[The Queen's Beasts]] began. {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="7" |Bullion coins |- ! !Type !Face Value !'''Diameter''' !Weight !Fineness !{{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}} |- | rowspan="2" |'''[[Britannia (coin)|Britannia]]''' |One Ounce Silver |£2 |38.61mm |31.21g |999 | |- |One Ounce Gold |£100 |32.69mm |31.21g |999.9 |{{Cite web|url=https://taxfreegold.co.uk/britanniasindx.html|title=Gold Britannias Index Page|last=|first=|date=|website=taxfreegold.co.uk|access-date=30 April 2017}} |- |'''[[Sovereign (British coin)|Sovereign]]''' |Sovereign |£1 |22.05mm |7.988g |.916 |{{Cite web|url=https://taxfreegold.co.uk/sovereignsinfo.html|title=British Gold Sovereigns - Information|last=|first=|date=|website=taxfreegold.co.uk|access-date=30 April 2017}} |- | rowspan="3" |'''[[The Queen's Beasts (coin)|Queen's Beasts]]''' |Two Ounce Silver |£5 |38.61mm |62.42g |999 | rowspan="3" |{{Cite web|url=https://taxfreegold.co.uk/queensbeastsgoldcoins.html|title=British Queen's Beasts Coin Series|last=|first=|date=|website=taxfreegold.co.uk|access-date=30 April 2017}} |- |One Ounce Gold |£100 |32.69mm |31.21g |999.9 |- |One Ounce Platinum |£100 |32.69mm |31.21g |999.5 |- | rowspan="2" |'''[[Lunar Series (British coin)|Lunar Series]]''' |One Ounce Silver |£2 |38.61mm |31.21g |999 | rowspan="2" |{{Cite web|url=https://taxfreegold.co.uk/royalmintchineselunarcalendargoldcoins.html|title=British Chinese Lunar Calendar Coins|last=|first=|date=|website=taxfreegold.co.uk|access-date=30 April 2017}} |- |One Ounce Gold |£100 |32.69mm |31.21g |999.9 |- |[[Landmarks of Britain]] |One Ounce Silver |£2 |38.61mm |31.21g |999 |{{Cite web|url=https://www.royalmintbullion.com/Products/Landmarks-Of-Britain/Silver|title=Landmarks Of Britain Silver Coins|last=|first=|date=|website=Royal Mint Bullion|access-date=21 September 2017}} |} === Medals === On occasion, the mint produces medals for government departments and under private contract for clients such as Royal societies, colleges and universities. Most notably the mint has made [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] medals as well as many military honours including the [[Defence Medal (United Kingdom)|Defence Medal]] and the [[Conspicuous Gallantry Cross]] for the [[British Armed Forces]].{{Cite web|url=http://blog.royalmint.com/a-badge-of-honour-our-pride-in-making-medals-at-the-royal-mint/|title=A badge of honour – our pride in making medals at The Royal Mint|last=|first=|date=|website=Royal Mint Blog|access-date=24 September 2017}} For the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] the mint won a contract to produce 4,700 gold, silver and bronze medals for competitors.{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/london-olympics-business/8207463/London-2012-Olympics-Royal-Mint-wins-contract-to-make-medals.html|title=London 2012 Olympics: Royal Mint wins contract to make medals|last=Ruddick|first=Graham|date=16 December 2010|work=The Telegraph|access-date=30 April 2017}} Prior to 1851, the making of medals at the mint was at the discretion of engravers who could undertake the work independently and receive and additional wage. A Royal patent which was issued in 1669 granted the mint the sole right to produce medals of any metal which bore a portrait of a monarch. Engravers would use the facilities at the mint to make commemorative medals to their own design for sale. A key date in the mint's history of producing medals for the military is 1815 when the [[Battle of Waterloo]] marked the beginning of awarding military campaign medals. By 1874 the mint was responsible for making all bars and clasps for war medals in the country and was making campaign medals such as the [[New Zealand Medal]], the [[Abyssinian War Medal]] and the [[Ashantee Medal]].{{cite web|title=Royal Mint: Medals|url=http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/r/C11028|publisher=[[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|The National Archive]]|accessdate=24 September 2017}} At the start of the [[World War I|First World War]], military medals were manufactured by the [[Royal Arsenal|Woolwich Arsenal]] and private contractors, however in 1922 a new medal unit created by the mint became the sole manufacturer of all Royal and State medals and decorations in metal, except the [[Victoria Cross]] which is made by [[Hancocks & Co]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.hancocks-london.com/the-victoria-cross/|title=Victoria Cross|last=|first=|date=|website=hancocks-london.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170924230657/https://www.hancocks-london.com/the-victoria-cross/|archive-date=2017-09-24|dead-url=yes|access-date=20 April 2017}} Prior to 2010, all British military medals were made by the mint however now must compete with other manufacturers.{{citation needed|date=November 2018}} File:The Waterloo Medal MET DP118486.jpg|alt=Waterloo Medal|[[Waterloo Medal (Pistrucci)|Waterloo Medal]] (1849) File:USA London 2012 Silver Medal Front.jpg|alt=2012 Olympic Medal|[[2012 Summer Olympics]] File:Military Cross.jpg|alt=Military Cross Medal|[[Military Cross]] File:George Cross.jpg|alt=George Cross Medal|[[George Cross]] File:Arctic Star medal.jpg|alt=Arctic Star Medal|[[Arctic Star]] ==Trial of the Pyx== The [[Trial of the Pyx]] is the procedure in the United Kingdom for ensuring that newly-[[Mint (coin)|minted]] [[British coinage|coins]] conform to required standards. The trials have been held since the twelfth century, normally once per calendar year, and continue to the present day. The form of the ceremony has been essentially the same since 1282. They are [[trial (law)|trials]] in the full judicial sense, presided over by a judge with an expert jury of [[Metallurgical assay|assayer]]s. Since 1871, the trials have taken place at the Hall of the [[Worshipful Company of Goldsmiths]], having previously taken place at the [[Palace of Westminster]].{{cite web|title=The Trial of the Pyx|url=http://www.thegoldsmiths.co.uk/company/trial.htm|accessdate=2 September 2008|publisher=The Goldsmiths' Company|year=2004|work=The Goldsmiths' Company}} Given modern production methods, it is unlikely that coins would not conform, although this has been a problem in the past as it would have been tempting for the [[Master of the Mint]] to steal [[precious metals]]. The term "Pyx" refers to the [[boxwood (genus)|boxwood]] chest (in [[Greek language|Greek]], πυξίς, ''pyxis'') in which coins were placed for presentation to the jury. There is also a Pyx Chapel (or Pyx Chamber) in [[Westminster Abbey]], which was once used for secure storage of the Pyx and related articles. Coins to be tested are drawn from the regular production of The Royal Mint. The Deputy Master of the Mint must, throughout the year, randomly select several thousand sample coins and place them aside for the Trial. These must be in a certain fixed proportion to the number of coins produced. For example, for every 5,000 bimetallic coins issued, one must be set aside, but for silver [[Maundy money]] the proportion is one in 150. The trial today consists of an inquiry independent of the royal mint{{cite web|url=http://www.royalmintmuseum.org.uk/history/history-of-the-royal-mint/trial-of-the-pyx/index.html|title=Trial of the Pyx|website=[[Royal Mint Museum]]|accessdate=25 September 2017}} The jury is composed of [[Freedom of the Company|Freemen]] of the [[Worshipful Company of Goldsmiths|Company of Goldsmiths]], who assay the coins provided to decide whether they have been minted within the criteria determined by the relevant Coinage Acts.{{cite web |title=The History of the Trial of the Pyx |url=http://www.royalmint.com/discover/uk-coins/history-of-the-trial-of-the-pyx |accessdate=27 March 2012 |publisher=The Royal Mint |date=27 March 2012 |work= }} ==See also== {{Portal|United Kingdom|Numismatics}} * [[List of British banknotes and coins]] * [[Coins of the pound sterling]] * [[Banknotes of the pound sterling]] * [[George Frederick Ansell]] * [[William John Hocking]] * [[Joseph Harris (British astronomer)]] * [[List of Mints]] * [[Mints of Scotland]] * [[Kevin Clancy (Royal Mint)|Kevin Clancy]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== {{refbegin|30em|ref=harv}} * {{Cite book|title=The Encyclopedia of Money|last=Allen|first=Larry|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|date=2009|isbn=978-1598842517|location=|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|last1=Ansell|first1=George Frederick|title=The Royal Mint: its working, conduct, and operations...|date=1870|publisher=Effingham Wilson, Royal Exchange|location=London|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=b1ZKAAAAYAAJ|ref=harv}} * {{Cite book|title=The Spellmount Guide to London in the Second World War|last=Beardon|first=James|publisher=Spellmount|year=2013|isbn=|location=|pages=177|ref=harv}} * {{Cite book|title=A New History of the Royal Mint|last=Challis|first=C. E.|publisher=Cambridge University Press|date=1992|isbn=|location=|ref=harv}} * {{Cite book|title=The Mint: A History of the London Mint from A.D. 287 to 1948 |last=Craig|first=John|publisher=Cambridge University Press|date=2011|isbn=|location=|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|last1=Davis|first1=Glyn|title=A History of Money From Ancient Times to the Present Day|date=2010|publisher=University of Wales Press|isbn=978-0708317174|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|last1=Dyer|first1=G.P.|title=The Royal Mint : An Illustrated History|date=1986|publisher=Royal Mint|isbn=9781869917012|ref=harv}} * {{Cite book|title=New Westminster Album: Glimpses of the City as It Was|last=Hainsworth|first=Gavin|publisher=Dundurn Group Ltd|date=2005|isbn=978-1550025484|location=|pages=148|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EW-4yJAi7YcC|title=Hong Kong: A Cultural History|date=2007|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-972447-5|page=70|last=Ingham|first=Michael|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|last1=Linecar|first1=Howard|title=Coins and Coin Collecting|date=1985|publisher=Littlehampton Book Services Ltd|isbn=9780600500872|ref=harv}} * {{Cite book|title=2017 Standard Catalog of World Coins, 1901-2000|last=Michael|first=Thomas|publisher=Krause Publications|date=2016|isbn=1440246548|location=|pages=|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|last=Vince|first= Alan|year=2001|title=London|editors= Lapidge, Michael; Blair, John; Keynes, Simon; Scragg, Donald |encyclopedia=The Blackwell Encyclopedia of Anglo-Saxon England |publisher= Blackwell |isbn=978-0-631-22492-1|ref=harv}} {{refend|ref=harv}} ==External links== * [http://www.royalmint.com The Royal Mint – official website] * [http://blog.royalmint.com/ The Royal Mint – official blog] * [https://www.facebook.com/theroyalmint The Royal Mint – Facebook] * [https://twitter.com/RoyalMintUK The Royal Mint – Twitter] * [http://instagram.com/RoyalMintUK The Royal Mint – Instagram] * [http://pinterest.com/RoyalMint The Royal Mint – Pinterest] * [https://plus.google.com/+royalmint The Royal Mint – Google Plus] * [http://www.royalmintmuseum.org.uk/ The Royal Mint Museum] * [https://onlinecoin.club/Info/Mints/Royal_Mint/ Coins minted by the Royal Mint] {{Mints in the United Kingdom|state=expanded}} {{HM Treasury}} {{coord|51.5542|-3.3889|type:landmark_region:GB-RCT|display=title}} [[Category:886 establishments]] [[Category:Coin mints]] [[Category:Mints of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Government-owned companies of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Currencies of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:9th-century establishments in England]] [[Category:Currencies of England]] [[Category:Tower of London]] [[Category:History of London]] [[Category:Economy of London]] [[Category:Llantrisant]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Rhondda Cynon Taf]] [[Category:Bullion dealers]] [[Category:Companies based in Rhondda Cynon Taf]] [[Category:Organisations based in Wales with royal patronage]]
